intro: Penstemon acuminatus var. minor, commonly known as the narrow-leaved beardtongue, is a perennial herb native to the western United States. It features showy, tubular flowers that range in color from pink to purple, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and native plant landscapes. Its nectar-rich flowers attract bees and other pollinators, contributing to its ecological value.
